Allows you to see the active collision info for the physics engine.

(Also catches that the glow buffer mode wasn't added to the empty template, apparently?)

data.body: like, say, assertfatal, to allow clicking in the popup.

data.title: Dedicated server console in Liunx is unresponsive
data.body:
If I start a dedicated server in Ubuntu via shell command:

``` sh
$ ./Torque -dedicated
```

I get a console prompt (`%`) but cannot type.

data.title: warning C4005: 'WIN32' : macro redefinition
warning C4706: assignment within conditional expression
case sensitivity fix for linux
Windows opengl includes do not assert or warn about case sensitivity
data.body: Breaks linux. Should probably look into that, though at time of writing, all _stock_ files behave themselves.

data.title: SDL mouse wheel speed fix.
data.body: Default scroll speed wasn't delta-modified, so scroll gui controls were very slow when scrolled via mouse wheel.. This corrects the issue.

data.title: Fixes the menubar functionality when using SDL.
data.body:
This resolves menu order, cleanup and close/re-open issues, as well as crashes on close.

It also modifies the look slightly to look closer to the windows menubar to keep a cohesive look regardless of platform.

data.title: Flips SDL_STATIC on to correct it creating bad symlinks
data.body: Despite the variable name, it does not, in fact create a static library, it would seem.

data.title: -wall leads to incredibly long compile times
data.body:
(we're talking 5 minutes vs 80, here)

Alternatively, someone more competent at dealing with cmake could look into string concatenation + a switch to expose it as an option for folks that really really want to know about every possible boo-boo.

data.title: sdl2 menu bar causing fatal assertions (windows)
data.body:
Sdl2 menu bar, specifically in a mission (so gui editor works) causes a fatal assertion. callstack:

```
Development_DEBUG.exe!dStrcmp(const char * str1, const char * str2) Line 62 C++
```

>   Development_DEBUG.exe!MenuBar::updateMenuBar(PopupMenu \* popupMenu) Line 115    C++
>     Development_DEBUG.exe!MenuBar::removeObject(SimObject \* obj) Line 69    C++
>     Development_DEBUG.exe!cm_SimSet_remove(SimSet \* object, int argc, ConsoleValueRef \* argv) Line 937  C++
>     Development_DEBUG.exe!cm_SimSet_remove_caster(SimObject \* object, int argc, ConsoleValueRef \* argv) Line 929    C++
>     Development_DEBUG.exe!CodeBlock::exec(unsigned int ip, const char \* functionName, Namespace \* thisNamespace, unsigned int argc, ConsoleValueRef \* argv, bool noCalls, const char \* packageName, int setFrame) Line 1945 C++

equates to:

https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/c152ae86f3f09b3c1d736954b352723d274582f1/Engine/source/platformSDL/menus/menuBarSDL.cpp#L115
to
https://github.com/GarageGames/Torque3D/blob/9bf6e0f8f499d3ed910fce357d70eaff59ffee39/Engine/source/core/strings/stringFunctions.h#L61

data.title: C4189 warning cleanups
data.body:
Addresses roughly half of the C4189 warnings though the following methodologies:

1) truly unused vars removed
2) vars leading to remmed out code for debugging remmed in turn.

left out:
vars in macros.

data.title: Properly testing pointer vars aren't null before using them.
data.body:
Issue found by PVS Studio:

Several instances where we utilize a pointer variable without properly testing that they aren't null first.

data.title: Ribbons in the editors
data.body: This lets you create ribbons from the editors easily for experimentation purposes. See screenshot [here](http://torque3d.wdfiles.com/local--files/scripter:creating-ribbons/ribbon.png).

data.title: Local variables shadowing other locals
data.body:
This causes a lot of warnings in VS. My approach to resolving these has been:
- Can the previous variable be used without being redeclared?
- Can either the shadowing or shadowed variable have a more specific/sensible name?
- Should both variables be renamed?

I don't think I've ever reduced the scope of a variable, though that might have been a viable strategy in some of these cases. I don't anticipate issues - I think I've been fairly careful. But scope is one of those tricky things...
